user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TaskDelete_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_TaskDelete_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_impl_task_internal_record_t *impl;
    void *                          retval;
    int                             ret;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_task_table, *token);

    /*
    ** Try to delete the task
    ** If this fails, not much recourse - the only potential cause of failure
    ** to cancel here is that the thread ID is invalid because it already exited itself,
    ** and if that is true there is nothing wrong - everything is OK to continue normally.
    */
    ret = pthread_cancel(impl->id);
    if (ret != 0)
    {
        OS_DEBUG("pthread_cancel: Failed on Task ID = %lu, err = %s\n",
                 OS_ObjectIdToInteger(OS_ObjectIdFromToken(token)), strerror(ret));

        /* fall through (will still return OS_SUCCESS) */
    }
    else
    {
        /*
         * Note that "pthread_cancel" is a request - and successful return above
         * only means that the cancellation request is pending.
         *
         * pthread_join() will wait until the thread has actually exited.
         *
         * This is important for CFE, as task deletion often occurs in
         * conjunction with an application reload - which means the next
         * call is likely to be OS_ModuleUnload().  So is critical that all
         * tasks potentially executing code within that module have actually
         * been stopped - not just pending cancellation.
         */
        ret = pthread_join(impl->id, &retval);
        if (ret != 0)
        {
            OS_DEBUG("pthread_join: Failed on Task ID = %lu, err = %s\n",
                     OS_ObjectIdToInteger(OS_ObjectIdFromToken(token)), strerror(ret));
        }
    }
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_TaskDelete_Impl:
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_impl_task_internal_record_t OS_impl_task_table[OS_MAX_TASKS]
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_t id;
} OS_impl_task_internal_record_t
...
static inline osal_id_t OS_ObjectIdFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_id;
}
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
static inline unsigned long OS_ObjectIdToInteger(osal_id_t object_id)
{
#ifdef OSAL_OMIT_DEPRECATED
    return object_id.v;
#else
    return object_id;
#endif
}
...
#define OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
OS_DEBUG("pthread_join: Failed on Task ID = %lu, err = %s\n",
                     OS_ObjectIdToInteger(OS_ObjectIdFromToken(token)), strerror(ret));

OS_DEBUG("pthread_cancel: Failed on Task ID = %lu, err = %s\n",
                 OS_ObjectIdToInteger(OS_ObjectIdFromToken(token)), strerror(ret));
explanation: The remainder of the function does not modify the function parameter itself. There are no assignments to the parameter variable 'token' (no statements like 'token = ...'), and the only other operations are: reading fields via inline accessor functions that take a pointer to const (they do not modify the token), performing pthread_cancel/pthread_join on the retrieved impl->id (operating on the impl local), using local variables (impl, retval, ret), and returning a constant. The OS_DEBUG macro is a no-op (empty) in the provided configuration. Therefore, aside from the reported fragments which involve taking/using the token in macros or debug calls and should be checked for inadvertent modification of the parameter or of its address, there are no other places in this function that warrant investigation under MISRA C Rule 17.8.
